Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: SEMOIS: Secure Mobile Information Sharing System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid advancement of the wireless technologies provide new opportunities for mobile users to have easy access to real-time data, derive useful social information, and stay connected with business partners, colleagues and friends. Towards this end, mobile social networking applications have recently emerged to meet these needs. Current mobile social networking applications do not support advanced context-based services. Additionally, serious security and privacy concerns have been raised when accessing social networking applications either from fixed locations or on-the-go. This project aims to build a secure mobile information sharing system (SEMOIS) that supports secure and privacy-preserving real-time information sharing. SEMOIS has the ability to store secure data items with flexible access control at insecure storage nodes and enables users to send context-based messages with late-binding features. SEMOIS achieves data confidentiality and privacy-preserving through data encryption and encrypted search, and enables intentional name based message dissemination without apriori knowledge of recipients. Additionally, a set of smart learning methods are developed to extract short-term and long-term geo-social patterns from multimodal sensing data collected by mobile devices for social networking purposes, e.g., geo-social patterns are used to derive hidden communities.

Project results are expected to advance the state of the art techniques for supporting secure and privacy-preserving mobile social networks with a variety of innovative features. The project equips both graduate and undergraduate students with the necessary background and practical skills for survival in the emerging job market and further contributes to the development of the pervasive computing field. In addition, SEMOIS can be used by middle and high school students from the Tri-State area that participate in the CHOICES and NSF-funded STEM program organized by Lehigh University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have designed several useful mobile data sharing platforms, namely

(i) intelligent vaccine distribution for effective disease control where we identifies patients' strong social ties using the dynamic community information extracted from contact traces collected via mobile devices and use such information to determine how to distribute limited vacinnes to people with higher risk of getting a particular contagious disease. Such a system will be very useful for future disease outbreak scenerios e.g. the recent Ebola outbreak, (research done in 2011-2012)

(ii) efficient incentive-based data sharing scheme in delay tolerant networks. Such a scheme provides incentives for mobile users to help forward data items of interest to others using opportunistic peer-to-peer links. Such a scheme is very useful in large disaster-response scenerios e.g. typhoons, earth-quake when users want to share information quickly with others using opportunistic peer-to-peer links, (research done in 2012-2013)

(iii) efficient on-device mobile visual search system where users can launch image-based searches using mobile devices. Again such a system is very important in emergency-related scenarios e.g. Boston Marathon events where law enforcement personnel can immediately share photos of suspects with mobile users to look for personal images which may contain the suspect, (research done in 2014.2015)

(iv) low cost gait-based user authentication scheme for mobile healthcare monitoring system. Our design allows mobile healthcare monitoring systems to defend against adversaries who may use others' monitored data to gain benefits. Our design exploits the fact that each individual's gait patterns are unique. Our design scheme is robust against users' varying walking sppeds and is robust against random or mimic attacks where adversaries have the opportunity to see how a user walks and try to mimic his walking style. (research done in 2014/2015)

(v) an online visual tracking using temporally coherent part clusters is designed such that our system can track human activitiies using 3D skeleton data. Our design is robust against deformations and occulsions. Evaluation results using popular challenging Kinect-based datasets show that our performance is better than state of the art methods. Our results are published in an IEEE WACV 2015 paper (research done in 2014/2015).
